question: Do activated oncogenes generate reactive oxygen species that cause oxidative DNA damage and increase genomic instability in leukemia cells? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: We find that BCR/ABL-induced reactive oxygen species (ROSs) cause chronic oxidative DNA damage resulting in double-strand breaks (DSBs) in S and G(2)/M cell cycle phases.
content.source_2: Contrary to prior reports, expression of BCR/ABL in Philadelphia chromosomeâ€“positive leukemic cells failed to elevate basal DNA damage markers, coinciding with reduced ROS levels and upregulation of antioxidant enzymes, consistent with preserved genomic stability.
content.source_3: We propose that the following series of events may contribute to genomic instability of Ph-positive leukemias: BCR/ABL --> ROSs --> oxidative DNA damage --> DSBs in proliferating cells --> unfaithful HRR and NHEJ repair.
content.source_4: In synchronized Ph-positive leukemia cultures, BCR/ABL-associated ROS production was sporadic and did not produce detectable oxidative DNA lesions or double-strand breaks across S or G(2)/M, and homology-directed as well as end-joining repair remained accurate, arguing against ROS-driven genomic instability.
